abstracts.cdata!:
A major pillar of the 2002 Country
            Assistance Strategy (CAS) for Poland, is to enhance private
            sector-led growth, and employment creation through
            enterprise restructuring, and, support for coal sector
            reform was included as a priority within that pillar in the
            CAS. The Hard Coal Mine Closure Project will directly
            support the physical closure, and environmental reclamation
            of excess coal mine capacity from CY 2004-2006. It envisages
            main economic and social objectives, that improve
            profitability, and the financial liquidity of the sector,
            i.e., allows regular payments of its liabilities, including
            payments of environmental fees, and, mitigates the social
            consequences of the program's implementation. The
            objectives are to be achieved through reform, in the areas
            of industry structure, mine closure, employment and
            financial restructuring, and, privatization. Through its
            five components the project will, first, liquidate
            underground workings and shafts, remove equipment, and
            secure underground areas. This will entail closure of
            underground roadways through dams, and if necessary,
            dewatering should prevent water hazards to neighboring
            operating mines, keeping the underground partly functional.
            Following liquidation, demolition and clearing surface
            structures will take place. Activities include shafts
            liquidation, by isolating materials such as clay, closing
            with a cement cap; demolition of existing buildings, or, if
            possible, for sale option; dismantling of installations,
            structures, and equipment; stabilization of waste dumps,
            and, closure of tailings ponds. Preparation of a
            comprehensive dewatering master plan, environmental
            management plans, and mine closure plans, including
            engineering design studies and supporting documentation will
            be conducted. Land reclamation will be implemented in two
            phases: a) preparation of land for industrial activity,
            which will include clean up and ground leveling, and, b)
            preparation of land for recreational purposes, to include
            remediation actions, such as vegetation propagation.
            Finally, following the mine closure, monitoring and
            maintenance will take place, particularly emphasizing
            dewatering activities, as needed.
